Class Board

java.lang.Object
  Board

public class Board
extends java.lang.Object

The Board class does much of the work here, keeping track of what pieces are where, and drawing the board on the screen. It also provides an interface for the main method. In other words, it will be used by your main method, and will use your Piece objects.

Constructor Summary
Board()
          Builds a Board object, filling in the board array.

Constructor Detail

Board

public Board()
Builds a Board object, filling in the board array. You can either call setUpBoard, which sets up the full board, or setUpBeginningBoard, which only sets up Rooks.

Method Detail

whiteTurn

public boolean whiteTurn()
Returns whether or not it is white's turn, using the field whiteTurn

winner

public int winner()
Determines if the current board has a winner.

Returns:
-1, 0, or 1, depending on if it is a black win, a draw, or a white win, respectively.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Provides the String of the board to be printed. Depends upon each Piece having the proper toString itself. For example, if you have done: 
 Board b = new Board();
 System.out.println(b);
then the board will be printed to the Terminal. It may be helpful to have enlarged your terminal using Ctl+.
This method depends upon each Piece object having a correct toString().

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

makeMove

public void makeMove(java.lang.String from,
                     java.lang.String to)
              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
This method should be called by the main method in Chess to make a move; YOU SHOULD COMPLETELY UNDERSTAND THIS METHOD BEFORE WRITING PIECE.JAVA. This method depends upon Piece having the following methods:
  • getColor()
  • makeMove()
  • and for Step 4, mustBeOpen()

Parameters:
from - This String should contain a board location in algebraic notation (eg "a5"). The Piece in that location will be moved.
to - This String should also contain a board location in algebraic notation. The piece in location "from" will be moved to this location.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if, for any reason, that move isn't possible. Reasons include:
  • from or to not being valid Locations,
  • from not containing a Piece,
  • from having a Piece of the wrong color,
  • to having a Piece the same color as from,
  • the move is not a valid move for the Piece in from, or
  • depending on if you are before or after Step 4, Pieces being in the way of the move
